message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menarche by age 16 in the presence of normal growth and development of secondary sexual characteristics, or the absence of menarche by age 14 in the absence of growth and development of secondary sexual characteristics. Serum beta hCG is the best next step in evaluation in order to rule out pregnancy as a cause of primary amenorrhea. Pelvic ultrasound and left hand radiograph may be ordered later on, and serum FSH may be ordered depending on the results of the serum beta hCG test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of menses in a 17-year-old girl with normal secondary sexual characteristics suggests primary amenorrhea. Serum beta hCG should be ordered to rule out pregnancy. Pelvic ultrasound and left hand radiograph can help determine the presence of reproductive organs and bone age, respectively, but are not the initial tests to be performed. Serum FSH can be ordered if beta hCG is negative to evaluate for primary ovarian failure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pelvic ultrasound and left hand radiograph are not the best next step in the evaluation of primary amenorrhea, as they are not likely to reveal the underlying cause. Serum FSH may be helpful, but serum beta hCG is the best first step, as it will rule out pregnancy and can also detect rare cases of gestational trophoblastic disease, which can present with primary amenorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Primary amenorrhea in a patient with normal secondary sexual characteristics suggests a potential issue with reproductive hormones. Serum beta hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) should be ordered to rule out pregnancy, which could be causing the amenorrhea. A pelvic ultrasound may be ordered if beta hCG levels are normal to evaluate for any anatomical abnormalities. Left hand radiograph and serum FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) are not the best next steps in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient has not had a menstrual period, the first step in evaluation is to rule out pregnancy. Serum beta hCG is the most appropriate test to order as it detects the presence of human chorionic gonadotropin in the blood, which is produced by the placenta after implantation of a fertilized egg. The other options may be useful in evaluating other causes of primary amenorrhea, such as abnormalities in bone age or ovarian function, but the first step is to rule out pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has primary amenorrhea and no symptoms, and physical examination shows normal development of secondary sexual characteristics. The best next step would be to rule out pregnancy by ordering a serum beta hCG test. Pelvic ultrasound and left hand radiograph are not the first-line tests for primary amenorrhea. Serum FSH may be useful later in the evaluation, but first, pregnancy should be ruled out.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A pelvic ultrasound and left hand radiograph could be helpful in determining the cause of primary amenorrhea, but they are not the best next step. Serum beta hCG should be the first test ordered to rule out pregnancy as a cause of primary amenorrhea. Only if pregnancy is ruled out, then serum FSH can be used to evaluate for ovarian dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In evaluating primary amenorrhea, the first step is to determine if the patient has a functioning uterus and vagina. As physical examination demonstrated an age-appropriate degree of development of secondary sexual characteristics, it is likely that the patient has a functioning uterus and vagina. The next step would be to rule out pregnancy, which can be done with a serum beta hCG test. Pelvic ultrasound and left hand radiograph are not appropriate tests for evaluating primary amenorrhea, and serum FSH may be ordered later in the diagnostic workup.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Primary amenorrhea is the absence of menstruation by age 16 in the presence of normal growth and secondary sexual characteristics, or by age 14 without secondary sexual characteristics. The most appropriate next step should be to rule out pregnancy with a serum beta hCG test. Pelvic ultrasound and left hand radiograph can be helpful in evaluating for potential structural abnormalities, but would not be the initial step. Serum FSH can be more helpful in evaluating for secondary amenorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient has not had any menstrual periods, it is important to rule out pregnancy. Therefore, the best next step in the evaluation would be to order a serum beta hCG test to rule out pregnancy. Pelvic ultrasound and left hand radiograph may be helpful in other conditions causing primary amenorrhea, such as Müllerian agenesis and Turner syndrome, but they are not the best initial test. Serum FSH may also be helpful, but it is not the best initial test.
